conclusion: A semi-cylindrical transparent brick with refractive index n and radius r is positioned with AC as the diameter. The laser beam enters perpendicularly at point A initially and moves towards point C at a constant speed v.
The critical angle θc is the angle of incidence above which total internal reflection occurs. It's given by sin θc = 1/n.
As the laser beam moves from A to C, its incidence point on the semi-cylinder changes. Consider the point D on the arc where the beam exits the semi-cylinder.
The beam's incidence angle relative to the normal at point D is θ. For the beam to emerge, θ must be less than the critical angle θc.
When the beam is at position OD, the horizontal distance AD is r sin θ. The beam travels a distance AD horizontally due to its speed v.
The distance moved by the beam along AC is AD = vt. Use the relation AD = r sin θ to find sin θ = vt/r.
The beam emerges when sin θ = 1/n. Therefore, vt/r = 1/n.
The moment when the light emerges from the arc surface ABC is t = r/(vn).
